description: {"blocks":[{"key":"ab35o","text":"This protocol describes a method (\"3D-EdgeAngle\") to measure edge angles on 3D models. The method is semi-automated and script based. 3D-EdgeAngle illustrates an objective way of measuring the edge angle at cross sections along the entire tool edge in defined steps and also allows measurements at different distances perpendicular to the edge. Depending on the scale of analysis, three parameters can be controlled accordingly. Within this protocol, all steps, starting from the acquisition of the 3D data to the statistical analysis, are described. Although the method is script based, 3D-EdgeAngle can also be executed manually. The protocol illustrates both versions. The scripts applied to perform the edge angle measurements are incorporated in the protocol as Zenodo links.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":35,"length":12},{"style":"italic","offset":134,"length":12},{"style":"italic","offset":588,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dql66","text":"3D scanning ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"srop","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2je3j","text":"The three samples were scanned with an AICON smartScan-HE R8 from the manufacturer Hexagon (software version OptoCat 2018R1), featuring a blue light LED and two black and white cameras with 8 megapixels each. The S-150 FOV (field of view) used has a point-to-point distance of 33 Âµm.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3o43m","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"18dht","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5l96d","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"299cb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"451kj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ir0u","text":"The following settings have been used to scan the samples:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8dqlq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5e6sd","text":"I. Turning on the system","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ptf7","text":"Before using the AICON smartScan-HE R8 the system had to be warmed up for one hour in advance. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"28lu1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d66l7","text":"II. Calibaration","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5br7h","text":"The scanner was calibrated with the appropriate calibration plate. Accuracy was reached when the deviation of the calibration was  â¤ 7.5 Âµm for the FOV 150. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"euplp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2j84c","text":"III. Placing the sample","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"qh46","text":"Each sample was placed in the middle of the turntable. Polystyrene was used to keep the samples in place. All three samples were scanned in an upright position. The sample holder (polystryrene) was covered with a black cloth.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9is5c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4qilu","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"el8im","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fkieq","text":"Note that for the calibrated standard angle some extra target marks on the sample were needed to make the aligning between the single scans possible. Thus, adhesive paper tags with symbols were placed on the calibrated standard angle. Despite ungreasing the metal surface of the sample, the adhesive paper tags showed a tendency to peel off after a period of time.    ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a05pp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7m6e6","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":4,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"n7u","text":"IV. Acquisition settings  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fav4p","text":"\"Automatic \" was chosen as a scanning mode. This means, based on the rotation of the turntable, the scans get aligned. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75otm","text":"A new project was created named with the following structure \"objectnumber_FOV_yyyymmdd\".","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63mui","text":"The software offers the possibility to use clip planes to define parts of the FOV that will not be considered during the processing of the 3D model (i.e. the turntable and the sample holder). Thus, clip planes were defined, eliminating everything visible below the sample (Z-axis). For doing so, the software needs to be taught where the rotation axis is relative to the object and scanner. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"lqej","text":"For initialising the scanning process, the number of grabs per scan (= different shutter times for an HDR scan) was selected with 4. The HDR-factor was set to manual so that the shutter time per grabs needed to be defined (light exposure). Different exposure times were selected between the grabs, guaranteeing that every part of the sample was sufficiently exposed for at least one of the grabs. The gain was 1x. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dr61g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fdt45","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":5,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9lm33","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":6,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4uobp","text":"V. Data acquisition","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e10jq","text":"The number of scans per rotation (i.e. 360Â°) was defined with ten. For all scans, the chosen light settings stayed the same. After these ten scans, the sample was turned so that the previously covered parts of the samples were visible. A new 360Â° rotation with ten scans was performed. Sometimes, individual scans needed to be done before the turn of the sample could take place (when the alignment was not possible otherwise). After these two full rotations, the samples were scanned with as many single scans as needed to cover the entire surface of the samples adequately by moving the sample. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6nau6","text":"Approximately 20 to 27 scans per tool were needed to create a closed model. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b3434","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9o6l9","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":7,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bb8ek","text":"VI. Alignment ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9m79p","text":"After acquiring the scans, the alignment was started. After starting the process, the software calculates a RMS (root mean square) value, which was â¤ 7.5 Âµm Ã deviation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ft7g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ljr4","text":"    ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":8,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"85j1","text":"VII. Data processing ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"57ul3","text":"The single 3D data (raw data) was opened in full resolution. The 3D data was cleaned by using the editing tools avaiable in the software. Doing so, scanned data not belonging to the actual sample could be removed (e.g. background). After this, the data was aligned again (see step VI.). In a final step, the cleaned 3D data was merged in full resolution. The raw data was saved and the 3D model was exported  in an STL-format. {"blocks":[{"key":"ajiab","text":"Editing of the 3D model ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5cd1b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f84nr","text":"One prerequisite for the application of 3D-EdgeAngle method is a closed 3D model. Thus, the 3D model in the STL-format was edited in the free software GOM Inspect 2018 (2018 Hotfix 2, Rev. 111729). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fcjee","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"986vd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5dosj","text":"The following steps were completed for each sample:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"nhn0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1s75g","text":"I. Import 3D model ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6d3a7","text":"The file was imported and opened as a STL-format, as new part. As \"target element\" type \"mesh\" was chosen. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7jtt1","text":"In the right docking area, all information about the mesh could be seen.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"t3kl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cm8kg","text":"II. Preparation 3D model ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b2tbk","text":"Within the editing menu, individual points, which are not entirely connected to the 3D mesh were selected and deleted (edit -\u003e selection in 3D -\u003e other selections -\u003e select patches by number of points -\u003e max. percentage 5.0%;  edit -\u003e delete selected points).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cdvvt","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"as85d","text":"  ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ck285","text":"Then, existing holes in the mesh were filled by selecting all points of elements of the mesh (mesh turns red and number of holes can be checked in information;  operations -\u003e mesh-\u003e close holes -\u003e automatically/interactively -\u003e chose the max. hole size + max. number of edges).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4bb9r","text":" ","type":"align-center","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"14kgo","text":"    ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":1,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4h536","text":"","type":"align-center","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"agsbn","text":"After doing this step once, mesh errors were additionally eliminated (operations -\u003e mesh -\u003e other -\u003e eliminate mesh errors).  ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"89cq2","text":"Depending on the number of holes these two steps were repeated until zero holes were left.  ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fsrb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7jk21","text":"III. Alignment ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"53inc","text":"In a final step, the samples were orientated (e.g., in case of the artefact the sample was orientated accoring to its technological features) following these steps: operations -\u003e alignment -\u003e manual alignment -\u003e set matrix (first XYZ-rotation, then XYZ-translation)). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2olif","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ova2","text":"IV. Export ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"anvdm","text":"Each project was saved individually as a GOM Inspect file (*.ginspect). {"blocks":[{"key":"dn2e7","text":"Construction of the sections ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3tpuo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bv189","text":"The \"reference curve\" is used for only one purpose, which is the definition of the sections. The sections are the cross profiles originating perpendicular from the \"reference curve\" and following the artefact surface for a defined length. These sections are also polylines as the vertical polylines along the edge and are always orientated in a 90Â° angle towards the \"reference curve\".  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bef8b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b0caq","text":"To present 3D-EdgeAngle,     per edge have been chosen as a parameter. In the manual version, however, the number of sections cannot be defined. Instead, the distance between the individual sections has to be determined. Thus, the distance has to be calculated.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":26,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"faeq3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"17rsl","text":"To do so, the \"reference curve\" has to be converted into an \"actual element\". ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"18mok","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4pe0g","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3oadk","text":"As soon as the \"reference curve\" is converted into an \"actual element\" , the length of the curve can be measured.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bmc8b","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d57ql","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6v20g","text":"The length in case of this \"reference curve\" is 82.29 mm. For ten sections in total, the lenght of the curve has to be divided by nine. Thus, the section distance is 9.14 mm.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"264dc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fsduk","text":"    ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5qo77","text":"After the sections have been constructed, each section can be exported individually in an IGES format. {"blocks":[{"key":"3qjgl","text":"a) 3-points procedure","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"51iq9","text":"The \"3-points\" measurement procedure is modelled on the  \"caliper method\" described by H. Dibble and M. Bernard in 1980.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":58,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3h88g","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"gfbo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cro44","text":"Whereas the result of the \"caliper method\" is based on a measurement taken by a special modified calliper at a known distance from the edge of the artefact by using a formula, the \"3-points\" digital measurement is using the same topographical indices, here represented by 3 points. The first point is the intersection between the vertical polyline (the \"surface curve\") and the horizontal polyline (the section). The two other points are placed on the section, each on one surface, in a defined distance away from the intersection (see #6.1). Following this triangulation, the edge angle can be calculated between these three points.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3sa6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2n4b","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"48luo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d8p35","text":"b) 2-lines procedure","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ofma","text":"The \"2-lines\" measurement procedure takes the intersection between the two polylines, as described in #6a, as one point. Beginning with this point, it follows the section on both surfaces for a given distance. Until this step, the two procedures are identical. Unlike the previous procedure, these points on the section (blue dots on the figure below) are used as starting points for the definition of two constructed lines. The constructed lines have a defined length (see #6.1) and take the points as a centre from where they expand in both directions. The extremities of these lines are placed on the section (blue lines on figure below) Thus, the calculation of the edge angle takes the two lines and the intersection into account. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cu6ff","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"13i9d","text":"   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c5h5p","text":"c) best-fit procedure","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7jja9","text":"The third way of calculating the edge angle, the \"best-fit\" procedure, is similar to the \"2-lines\" measurement. The difference is that the lines are constructed by finding the best fit along the defined length of the section. Therefore, the extremities of these lines are not necessarily placed on the section (blue lines on figure below).This has the advantage of reducing a possible error caused by small changes in the section direction. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ku8j","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"authors":"Harald Dibble, Mary C. Bernard","can_edit":1,"date":"337764070","doi":"https://doi.org/10.2307/280156","guid":"4608EB0A341A11ED98AD0A58A9FEAC02","id":1989,"journal":"American Antiquity, 45(4), 857-865","protocol_id":null,"title":"A Comparative Study of Basic Edge Angle Measurement Techniques"}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B0E15DF0F88211ED97F18BD1B4F1A8BA","height":201,"id":378138,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"9ksa9\",\"text\":\"Schematic {"blocks":[{"key":"9uk0h","text":"Parameter ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"utak","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2a3g","text":"The parameters chosen for presenting the method are exemplary. In total, three different parameters are relevant for an edge angle calculation. One of these three is the number of sections defined along the toolâs edge, chosen here to be ten sections per tool. It is possible to choose a fixed number of equidistant sections per tool, as done here, or to define steps, e.g., every few millimetres. Additionally, the length of the sections have to be defined, which are 12 mm long in this case (see different options in the GitHub/Zenodo release: sections_SEC_NUM or sections_SEC_DIST).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1lqva","text":"Another parameter is the distance between the intersection and the points on the sections. In all three described measuring procedures, the intersection between the surface curve and the section determines one crucial point, but the other two points per measurement have to be defined numerically. Implemented as values in this study are 2 mm, 5 mm, and 10 mm. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3pv74","text":"The last parameter is the lengths of the two constructed lines used in the \"2-lines\" and \"best- fit\" measuring procedures, which is here always 0.5 mm. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"78qdm","text":" ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
